newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: SOCCER-MARADONA WAS AT FLAT BEFORE DRUGS BUST, MANAGER SAYS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-MARADONA WAS AT FLAT BEFORE DRUGS BUST, MANAGER SAYS.

text.p: Diego Maradona's manager Guillermo Coppola, held on drug charges, has told a judge the Argentine soccer star was at his home with three women shortly before police found cocaine there, a prosecutor said Tuesday.

Coppola was arrested two weeks ago, along with Maradona's brother-in-law Gabriel Esposito, former soccer international Alberto Tarantini and others, after police found a pound (500 grams) of cocaine in a flower pot at Coppola's apartment.

State prosecutor Jorge Mola told local radio that in a six hour declaration to Judge Hernan Bernasconi on Monday, Coppola "brought new evidence about a party at his home a day before he left it, with Diego Maradona and other people he named."

And Bernasconi told radio stations that Coppola said he left the party, held the weekend before the raid, leaving Diego alone with three "well known but not famous women." The judge said he may have to question Maradona now.

The proceedings in Dolores provincial courthouse south of Buenos Aires have given ordinary Argentines a glimpse into the sleazy nightlife of a jet set where politicians, models and sports stars partied with drug dealers and prostitutes.

Many Argentines blame 49-year-old Coppola for Maradona's self-confessed cocaine habit, which put the 36-year-old Boca Juniors player in a Swiss clinic for 10 days last month. Days after checking out, he smashed up a Spanish hotel in a rage.

Bronzed, silver-haired Coppola, Maradona's manager and friend for most of the past decade, has had brushes with the law before, including drug-peddling charges in Italy while managing Maradona's career in Naples.

His arrest has embarrassed senior members of Argentina's government. Coppola was a visitor to President Carlos Menem's home with Maradona and was a friend of Menem's late son Carlitos and Menem's private secretary Ramon Hernandez.
But Bernasconi tried to cool down speculation about who would be arrested next: "The investigations may lead us along new paths, but I think expectations are exaggerated."

Coppola says he is a cocaine user but not a dealer and that the drugs were planted. His lawyer Mariano Cuneo Liberona wants Judge Bernasconi taken off the case because Coppola's Buenos Aires home is outside his provincial jurisdiction.
Bernasconi argued the case is within his jurisdiction since it was launched eight months ago as a drugs crackdown in beach resorts along Buenos Aires province's Atlantic coast.
